For the period of 18â21 January, the protocol for international travellers emphasises differentiation mainly regarding whether the traveller is from an "At Risk" country or not, rather than vaccination status.     1. Screening:   - Regardless of vaccination status, all travellers must have a negative result on their PCR test no more than 72 hours before departure. Travellers must also complete and submit a declaration form on the Air Suvidha Portal.   - Upon arrival, travellers from "Countries Specified At Risk" must take a PCR test and may not leave the airport until they receive their result.  - Travellers who are not from such countries do not ordinarily need to be tested, but PCR tests are carried out on a random sample (2%) of this group.     2. Quarantine: All travellers, regardless of vaccination status and country of origin, must quarantine for 7 days. It is not possible to "test out" of quarantine, even if one tests negative on PCR test taken at the airport.     3. Screening: A final PCR test is required on Day 8, with the result uploaded on the Air Suvidha Portal.    Archived sources:  1. As of January,05,2022, the Pakistani government has modified its international travel rules. Categorical classification of countries is no longer valid, effectively lifting travel bans from category C locations, including several African and European countries, and Hong Kong among others. Revised rules mandate inbound passengers to hold proof of completing vaccination if above 18 years old and negative results of a PCR test obtained within 48 hours before departure if older than six years. They must continue to submit a health declaration from online or via the Pass Track mobile application within 48 hours before arrival. Returning Pakistani citizens unable to avail of vaccination due to visa or medical issues, as well as Afghan citizens entering via land borders, are exempt from carrying vaccination certificate. Passengers arriving via direct flights from Europe will undergo an on arrival rapid antigen test (RAT); officials will also administer RAT to 50% of arrivals from Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the UAE, as well as a random selection of passengers from other countries. Passengers with positive RAT test results must quarantine for 10 days at a government or self-paid facility, those who test positive on the mandatory PCR test on the eighth day must undergo additional quarantine until they return negative result in a PCR test.
